facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 512 of 1957 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 512 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated August 29, 1952 of Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 2349 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 29 1952, of the Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 2349 of 1946.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 14, 1961 by Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. February 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.-

facts.text: Ancient Durgah with appurtenant Masjid exists in village Cavelong, District Chingleput, State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: There is in the village of Cavelong, District Chiugleput in the State of Madras an ancient Durgah to which is appurtenant a Masjid.

facts.text: Nawab of Carnatic granted two villages in inam for maintenance of Durgah and Masjid.

anchor.surface_text: The Nawab of Carnatic had granted two villages in inam for the maintenance of the Durgah and the Masjid.

facts.text: Income of institution shared equally by descendants in four families after expenses.

anchor.surface_text: The income of-the institution after disbursing the expenses of Sandal, and Urs and of feeding the poor has since long been shared by descendants in four families in equal shares.

facts.text: Custom excluded females and persons claiming through females from income share; distributed to males in male line.

anchor.surface_text: By Custom females and persons claiming through females were excluded from receiving a share of the income and the income was distributed amongst the males descended in the male fine.

facts.text: Scheme framed in Original Suit No. 27 of 1940 by Subordinate Judge, Chingleput; Board of trustees appointed.

anchor.surface_text: In original suit No. 27 of 1940 of the file of the Subordi- nate Judge, Chingleput, a scheme was framed for administration of the Durgah and the Masjid and a Board of trustees was appointed for that purpose.

facts.text: Fakruddin belonged to one of four families and received 1/8th share of income.

anchor.surface_text: Fakruddin, in the following genealogy, belonged to one of the four families which received the income. ... As a descendant of Sheik Mohammad, Fakruddin received a 1/8th share of. the income.

facts.text: Fakruddin entitled to perform Urs ceremony once in eight years.

anchor.surface_text: He was also by arrangement with others entitled to perform the Urs ceremony once in eight years.

facts.text: Fakruddin died in 1921 survived by wife Sulaiman Bi and daughters Rahmat Unnissa and Syed Unnissa.

anchor.surface_text: Fakruddin died in 1921 leaving him surviving his wife Sulaiman Bi and two daughters Rahmat Unnissa and Syed Unnissa.

facts.text: Sulaiman Bi is plaintiff No. 2, Syed Unnissa plaintiff No. 1, Rahmat Unnissa defendant No. 2 in suit No. 156 of 1937.

anchor.surface_text: Sulaiman Bi is plaintiff No. 2 and Rahmat Unnissa and Syed Unnissa are respectively defendant No. 2 and plaintiff No. 1 in suit No. 156 of 1937

facts.text: In 1926, Urs performed on behalf of Fakruddin's widow and daughters by their deputies.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1926, it was the turn of Fakruddin to perform the Urs and it is claimed by the plaintiffs that it was performed on behalf of the widow and daughters of Fakruddin by their deputies.

facts.text: In 1934, plaintiffs and defendant No. 2 obstructed by Abdul Wahid from performing Urs.

anchor.surface_text: The next turn was in the year 1934, but in the performance of the Urs, the plaintiffs and defendant No. 2 were obstructed by Abdul Wahid son of Nayeem-Uddin

facts.text: Suit No. 156 of 1937 filed by plaintiffs 1 and 2 in District Munsif, Chingleput.

anchor.surface_text: Plaintiffs 1 and 2 then filed suit No. 156 of 1937 in the companyrt of the District Munsif at Chingleput .

facts.text: Suit sought declaration of entitlement to manage Durgah, perform Urs every 8 years since 1934, receive incomes, and injunction against Abdul Wahid.

anchor.surface_text: For a declaration that they were entitled to enjoy the properties described in the schedule annexed to the plaint and to manage the Durgah, perform the Urs festival and receive all incomes, endowments and perquisites thereof once in every eight years since 1934 according to their turn. They also claimed an injunction

facts.text: Abdul Wahid (defendant No. 1) died during pendency of suit; defendants 4 to 10 brought on record as heirs excluding daughter of Abdul Wahid.

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Wahid defendant No. 1 died during the pendency of the suit and defendants 4 to 10 who were brought on record on their own application as heirs and legal representatives to the exclusion of the daughter of Abdul Wahid

facts.text: Defendants denied plaintiffs' right claiming custom excludes females from inheritance and offices, suit barred by limitation, not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: They denied the right of the plaintiffs to a share in the income companytending that lay custom in the family, females were excluded from inheritance, that the office of Peshimam, Khatib and Mujavar companyld only be held by males and that females were excluded from those offices, that the plaintiffs claim was barred by the law of limitation

facts.text: Trial Judge held immemorial custom precludes plaintiffs from services and income; dismissed suit. Appellate court agreed.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Judge held-and the appellate companyrt agreed with him that there was an immemorial custom governing the institutions precluding the plaintiffs from performing services or sharing the income, emoluments and perquisites

facts.text: Madras High Court in Second Appeal held Shariat Act 1937 applies; claim not barred by limitation; suit maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: In second appeal, the High Court at Madras held that by virtue of the Shariat Act, 1937, the income received from the institution had to be shared according to the per- sonal law of the parties and that the plaintiffs claim was number barred by the law of limitation number was the suit

facts.text: Plaintiff No. 1 was 19 years old at date of suit.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court hold that plaintiff No. 1 was at the date of the suit 19 years of age

facts.text: Plaintiffs not in enjoyment of Fakruddin's share since 1921.

anchor.surface_text: The trial judge hold that the plaintiffs were number in enjoyment of the share of Fakruddin since 1921

facts.text: Shariat Act, 1937 enacted; amended by Madras Act 18 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: But-the Act enacted by the Central Legislature was amended by Madras Act 18 of 1949

facts.text: Supreme Court held suit maintainable as declaration with consequential injunction.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the suit as framed was maintainable.

facts.text: Trial and first appellate courts held on evidence immemorial custom excludes females.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt as well as the first appellate companyrt held on an exhaustive review of the evidence that there was an immemorial custom governing the institutions

facts.text: Supreme Court held Shariat Act applies notwithstanding custom, even to pending suits.

anchor.surface_text: But since the enactment of the Shariat lot 26 of 1937, this custom must be deemed inapplicable to the members of the family.

facts.text: Duties of offices can be performed through deputies (trial court finding).

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt has found that the duties of those offices companyld be performed through deputies.

facts.text: Income distribution not conditional on performing duties of offices.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing on the record to suggest that the right to receive the income is companyditional upon the performance of the duties of the offices of Peshimam, Khatib and Mujavar.

facts.text: Trustees manage institution and distribute surplus income.

anchor.surface_text: The management of the institution is vested in the trustees.

facts.text: Four families entitled by tradition to perform ceremonies and share income.

anchor.surface_text: The four families, it is true, are by tradition entitled to perform and officiate at certain ceremonies and also to share in the income.
this appeal with special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution is preferred.

issues.text: Whether the suit as framed for declaration with consequential injunction is maintainable under s.42 Specific Relief Act

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the suit as framed was maintainable. The management of the institution is vested in the trustees. The four families, it is true, are by tradition entitled to perform and officiate at certain ceremonies and also to share in the income. A suit for declaration with a consequential relief for injunction, is not a suit for declaration simpliciter it is a suit for declaration with further relief.

issues.text: Whether the plaintiffs' suit is barred by limitation under the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: Whether the further relief claimed in a particular case as consequential upon a,declaration is adequate must always depend upon the facts and circumstances of each case. In Kunj Behari Prasadji Purshottam Prasadji v. Keshavlal Hiralal 1 , it was held that s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act does not empower the court to dismiss a suit for a declaration and injunction and that an injunction is a further relief within the meaning of s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act.

issues.text: Whether there was an immemorial custom excluding females from sharing income and performing services in the institution

anchor.surface_text: The trial court as well as the first appellate court held on an exhaustive review of the evidence that there was an immemorial custom governing the institutions whereby the plaintiffs were not entitled to perform service or share the income, emoluments and perquisites. But since the enactment of the Shariat Act 26 of 1937, this custom must be deemed inapplicable to the members of the family.

issues.text: Whether the Shariat Act 1937 as amended by Madras Act 18 of 1949 applies notwithstanding custom to wakfs and sharing of income and retrospectively to pending suits

anchor.surface_text: By s. 2 of the Act, it was enacted as follows Notwithstanding any customs or usage to the contrary in all questions save questions relating to agricultural lands regarding intestate succession, special property of females, including personal property inherited or obtained under contract or gift or any other provision of Personal Law, marriage, dissolution of marriage, including talaq, ila, zihar, lian, khula and mubarrat, maintenance, dower, guardianship, gifts, trusts and trust properties, and wakfs other than charities and charitable institutions and charitable and religious endowments the rule of decision in cases where the parties are Muslims shall be the Muslim Personal Law (Shariat).

issues.text: Whether under Muslim Personal Law females are excluded from offices of Peshimam, Khatib and Mujavar even through deputies

anchor.surface_text: The plea raised by counsel for the contesting defendants that even under the Muslim Personal Law, females are excluded from performing the duties of the offices of Peshimam, Khatib and Mujavar and that they cannot carry out the duties of those offices even through deputies is one which was not raised before the High Court.

issues.text: Whether right to receive income is conditional upon performance of duties of Peshimam, Khatib and Mujavar

anchor.surface_text: In any event, if the income was being distributed amongst the four families, the plaintiffs and defendant No. 2 claiming under Fakruddin would, by virtue of the provisions of the Shariat Act, be entitled to receive that income. There is nothing on the record to suggest that the right to receive the income is conditional upon the performance of the duties of the offices of Peshimam, Khatib and Mujavar.

arguments.claim: Suit not barred by limitation under art 120; accrues on trustees' infringement; minor extension ss6,8

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that plaintiff No. 1 was at the date of the suit 19 years of age and was entitled to file a suit for enforcement of her right even if the period of limitation had expired during her minority within three years from the date on which she attained majority by virtue of ss. 6 and 8 of the Indian Limitation Act.

But since the enactment of the Shariat Act 26 of 1937, this custom must be deemed inapplicable to the members of the family.

arguments.claim: Right to receive income not conditional on performance of duties of offices

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing on the record to suggest that the right to receive the income is conditional upon the performance of the duties of the offices of Peshimam, Khatib and Mujavar.

arguments.claim: Shariat Act not retrospective; does not affect vested rights or pending suits per Lahore HC

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view of the Lahore High Court in Syed Roshan Ali v. Mt. Behmat Bibi that a right acquired before 1937 ... was not taken away by the enactment of the Muslim Personal Law (Shariat) Application Act, 1937.

arguments.court_reasoning: Lahore HC ignored explicit language giving retrospective effect

holdings.text: The suit as framed was maintainable as it is a suit for declaration with consequential relief for injunction.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the suit as framed was maintainable. The management of the institution is vested in the trustees. The four families, it is true, are by tradition entitled to perform and officiate at certain ceremonies and also to share in the income. A suit for declaration with a consequential relief for injunction, is not a suit for declaration simpliciter it is a suit for declaration with further relief.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Management vested in trustees; families entitled by tradition to share income; injunction is consequential relief under s.42 Specific Relief Act; follows precedent in Kunj Behari case.

holdings.text: The suit is not barred by limitation under art.120 Limitation Act as right to sue accrues only on trustees' denial or threat, not co-defendants' denial; additionally, s.6 and 8 extend for minority.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the further relief claimed in a particular case as consequential upon a,declaration is adequate must always depend upon the facts and circumstances of each case. In Kunj Behari Prasadji Purshottam Prasadji v. Keshavlal Hiralal 1 , it was held that s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act does not empower the court to dismiss a suit for a declaration and injunction and that an injunction is a further relief within the meaning of s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff minor entitled to extension; trustees manage and have not denied rights; limitation runs from infringement by trustees, not contesting defendants.

holdings.text: Immemorial custom excluding females from income share and services existed but is inapplicable since enactment of Shariat Act 1937.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court as well as the first appellate court held on an exhaustive review of the evidence that there was an immemorial custom governing the institutions whereby the plaintiffs were not entitled to perform service or share the income, emoluments and perquisites. But since the enactment of the Shariat Act 26 of 1937, this custom must be deemed inapplicable to the members of the family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts lower courts' evidence finding of custom but holds Shariat Act overrides it notwithstanding custom clause.

holdings.text: Shariat Act 1937 as amended by Madras Act 18 of 1949 applies notwithstanding custom to wakfs and income sharing, retrospectively including to pending suits.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 2 of the Act, it was enacted as follows Notwithstanding any customs or usage to the contrary in all questions save questions relating to agricultural lands regarding intestate succession, special property of females, including personal property inherited or obtained under contract or gift or any other provision of Personal Law, marriage, dissolution of marriage, including talaq, ila, zihar, lian, khula and mubarrat, maintenance, dower, guardianship, gifts, trusts and trust properties, and wakfs other than charities and charitable institutions and charitable and religious endowments the rule of decision in cases where the parties are Muslims shall be the Muslim Personal Law (Shariat).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit 'notwithstanding custom' language rebuts presumption against retrospectivity; applies to all proceedings including pending; amendment removes charity exception for wakfs; distinguishes Lahore HC.

holdings.text: Contesting defendants not permitted to raise plea that under Muslim Personal Law females excluded from offices of Peshimam, Khatib, Mujavar even through deputies as not raised before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The plea raised by counsel for the contesting defendants that even under the Muslim Personal Law, females are excluded from performing the duties of the offices of Peshimam, Khatib and Mujavar and that they cannot carry out the duties of those offices even through deputies is one which was not raised before the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea not raised before High Court; trial court found duties performable through deputies; first appellate silent.

holdings.text: Right to receive income is not conditional upon performance of duties of offices of Peshimam, Khatib and Mujavar.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing on the record to suggest that the right to receive the income is conditional upon the performance of the duties of the offices of Peshimam, Khatib and Mujavar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence on record linking income right to duty performance.

holdings.text: Plaintiffs and defendant No.2 entitled to Fakruddin's share of income by virtue of Shariat Act.

anchor.surface_text: In any event, if the income was being distributed amongst the four families, the plaintiffs and defendant No. 2 claiming under Fakruddin would, by virtue of the provisions of the Shariat Act, be entitled to receive that income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Income distributed among four families; Shariat governs succession overriding custom; females entitled.

precedents.citation: Kunj Behari Prasadji Purshottam Prasadji v. Keshavlal Hiralal 1

anchor.surface_text: Kunj Behari Prasadji Purshottam Prasadji v. Keshavlal Hiralal 1 , it was held that s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act does number empower the companyrt to dismiss a suit for a declaration and injunction and that an injunction is a further relief within the meaning of s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act.

precedents.case_name: Kunj Behari Prasadji Purshottam Prasadji v. Keshavlal Hiralal
precedents.cited_proposition: s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act does not empower the court to dismiss a suit for a declaration and injunction; an injunction is further relief within s. 42

precedents.citation: Syed Roshan Ali-v. Mt. Behmat Bibi 1

anchor.surface_text: Syed Roshan Ali-v. Mt. Behmat Bibi 1  that a right acquired before 1937  the date on which the Shariat Act was brought into operation  to bring a suit for a declaration that the alienation by the widow of the last holder who had by custom succeeded to the limited estate left by her husband was number binding upon the reversioner, was number taken away by the enactment of the Muslim Personal Law  Shariat  Application Act, 1937.

precedents.case_name: Syed Roshan Ali v. Mt. Behmat Bibi
precedents.cited_proposition: a right acquired before 1937 to challenge alienation under custom was not taken away by the Shariat Act 1937

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the suit as framed was maintainable. The management of the institution is vested in the trustees. The four families, it is true, are by tradition entitled to perform and officiate at certain ceremonies and also to share in the income. A suit for declaration with a consequential relief for injunction, is not a suit for declaration simpliciter it is a suit for declaration with further relief.
In our view, the High Court was right in holding that it was bound to apply the provisions of the Shariat Act as amended by Madras Act 18 of 1949 to the suit filed by the plaintiffs.
by the High Court, this appeal with special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution is preferred. In our view, the suit as framed was maintainable. T

edges.explanation: Holding h2 concludes suit not barred by limitation under art.120, additionally citing s.6 and 8, directly addressing issue i2

anchor.surface_text: Whether the further relief claimed in a particular case as consequential upon a,declaration is adequate must always depend upon the facts and circumstances of each case. In Kunj Behari Prasadji Purshottam Prasadji v. Keshavlal Hiralal 1 , it was held that s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act does not empower the court to dismiss a suit for a declaration and injunction and that an injunction is a further relief within the meaning of s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act.
In our view, the High Court was right in holding that it was bound to apply the provisions of the Shariat Act as amended by Madras Act 18 of 1949 to the suit filed by the plaintiffs.

edges.explanation: Finding custom inapplicable due to Shariat supports holding on Shariat's applicability

anchor.surface_text: The trial court as well as the first appellate court held on an exhaustive review of the evidence that there was an immemorial custom governing the institutions whereby the plaintiffs were not entitled to perform service or share the income, emoluments and perquisites. But since the enactment of the Shariat Act 26 of 1937, this custom must be deemed inapplicable to the members of the family.
In our view, the High Court was right in holding that it was bound to apply the provisions of the Shariat Act as amended by Madras Act 18 of 1949 to the suit filed by the plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 2 of the Act, it was enacted as follows Notwithstanding any customs or usage to the contrary in all questions save questions relating to agricultural lands regarding intestate succession, special property of females, including personal property inherited or obtained under contract or gift or any other provision of Personal Law, marriage, dissolution of marriage, including talaq, ila, zihar, lian, khula and mubarrat, maintenance, dower, guardianship, gifts, trusts and trust properties, and wakfs other than charities and charitable institutions and charitable and religious endowments the rule of decision in cases where the parties are Muslims shall be the Muslim Personal Law (Shariat).
In our view, the High Court was right in holding that it was bound to apply the provisions of the Shariat Act as amended by Madras Act 18 of 1949 to the suit filed by the plaintiffs.
High Court was right in holding that it was bound to apply the provisions of the Shariat Act as amended by Madras Act 18 of 1949 to the suit filed by

edges.explanation: Holding explicitly bars the plea that under Muslim Personal Law females are excluded from the offices even through deputies, directly addressing the issue.

anchor.surface_text: The plea raised by counsel for the contesting defendants that even under the Muslim Personal Law, females are excluded from performing the duties of the offices of Peshimam, Khatib and Mujavar and that they cannot carry out the duties of those offices even through deputies is one which was not raised before the High Court.
In our view, the High Court was right in holding that it was bound to apply the provisions of the Shariat Act as amended by Madras Act 18 of 1949 to the suit filed by the plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing on the record to suggest that the right to receive the income is conditional upon the performance of the duties of the offices of Peshimam, Khatib and Mujavar.
In our view, the High Court was right in holding that it was bound to apply the provisions of the Shariat Act as amended by Madras Act 18 of 1949 to the suit filed by the plaintiffs.
